title.value: Caustics: A Python Package for Accelerated Strong Gravitational Lensing Simulations
title.justification: The title is taken directly from the front matter of the paper, which specifies the focus and scope of the research.
title.quote:
Caustics: A Python Package for Accelerated
Strong Gravitational Lensing Simulations

extractions.description: The paper presents 'caustics', a Python package designed to handle the computational demands of modeling a vast number of strong gravitational lensing systems. The package aims to accelerate processing using PyTorch and offers tools for deep learning and automatic differentiation to facilitate machine learning applications in gravitational lensing simulations.

type.justification: The paper discusses the development and capabilities of the 'caustics' software and presents empirical performance enhancements for simulations.
type.quote: Caustics fulfills a timely need for a differentiable lensing simulator.

name.justification: The paper discusses a Python package for simulating strong gravitational lensing, which is a topic in astrophysics that also utilizes machine learning methods for data processing and analysis.
name.quote:
Gravitational lensing is the deflection of light rays due to the gravity of intervening
masses.

name.justification: The focus of the paper is on simulating strong gravitational lensing systems.
name.quote: Caustics is a gravitational lensing simulator.

name.justification: The paper emphasizes the integration of deep learning and machine learning techniques in processing and analyzing lensing simulations.
name.quote:
Machine learning will be critical to achieve the necessary speed to process these
lenses, it will also be needed to meet the complexity of strong lens modelling.

name.justification: PyTorch is explicitly mentioned as a core component of the 'caustics' package for deep learning and automatic differentiation.
name.quote: caustics is built with the future of lensing in mind, using PyTorch (Paszke et al., 2019) to accelerate the low level computation and enable deep learning algorithms which rely on automatic differentiation.
